briefing.opening: Good morning. Welcome to the climate briefing for December 22, 2025. Today's briefing will primarily cover domestic and international efforts to address climate change, along with updates on the deepening crisis and the successes and challenges of international cooperation.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡·ğŸŒ± Accelerating Domestic Carbon Neutrality Implementation and Policy Trends
sections.content: As of December 22, 2025, the Republic of Korea continues its diverse efforts to transition to a carbon-neutral society. At the national level, the 4th 'National Climate Crisis Proactive Response Plan' has been established, and the 2035 National Greenhouse Gas Reduction Target (NDC) has been finalized, presenting more specific goals [6, 7]. The Ministry of Climate has launched a 'DXÂ·AX Strategy Task Force' utilizing Artificial Intelligence (AI) to accelerate the achievement of carbon neutrality goals, while the Korea Gas Safety Corporation is solidifying the technological foundation by establishing one national standard (KS) in the Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) sector [19, 20]. Various local governments and communities [1, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 18, 22, 25, 26, 28] and the financial sector [17, 21, 24] are also actively pursuing carbon neutrality, including Gunsan City's energy self-sufficiency infrastructure construction project to achieve its 2025 carbon neutrality goal [23], Gangwon Self-Governing Province's climate response investments such as drought measures [4], and Busan Nakdonggang Garden's blue carbon utilization cooperation [9]. Furthermore, discussions are active in the National Assembly regarding strengthening the legal and institutional framework, with a proposed amendment to the Framework Act on Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth for Climate Crisis Response [27].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡·âš ï¸ Progress and Challenges in Domestic Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: As the climate crisis becomes a reality, the transition of domestic industrial and energy structures is accelerating, and efforts to shift towards renewable energy continue [5]. Jeollanam-do Province, in particular, as a leading region in renewable energy, is accelerating the development of new and renewable energy and advanced strategic industries through cooperation with the Korea Development Bank. It is also speeding up the promotion of factory rooftop solar power generation and the review of 'Energy Highway' project achievements to reach the 100GW renewable energy target [29, 31, 33, 34, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 45]. Minister Kim Sung-hwan stated that nuclear power and renewable energy are not incompatible energy sources, suggesting the possibility of a harmonious energy mix [30, 44]. However, an analysis indicating that weather variability is affecting the profitability formula of renewable energy, impacting wind speed, facility utilization rates, and even financial conditions, shows that many challenges still need to be addressed for renewable energy expansion [35]. Furthermore, heat pumps, considered an essential policy for achieving carbon neutrality, continue to be a subject of debate due to high initial costs and energy tariff structures [12].

sections.title: ğŸŒğŸ”´ Deepening Global Climate Crisis and Increasing Vulnerability
sections.content: Globally, the severe impacts of climate change are becoming visible, with growing concerns particularly for vulnerable populations and regions. In Pakistan, climate justice protests have erupted due to grievances over severe floods and smog [8], and in the Alps, research indicates that glaciers are rapidly disappearing due to climate change, leading to an increase in fatalities from glacial floods [66, 80]. Furthermore, a study suggesting that heat and humidity caused by climate change could increase stunting among children in South Asia warns of a serious threat to the growth of millions of children [50, 73, 74, 78]. These phenomena demonstrate that a global experiment is unfolding in real-time [60], and with the impacts of climate change even being mentioned during the Christmas season [49, 54], it suggests that the climate crisis is becoming a reality across all aspects of daily life.

sections.title: ğŸŒğŸŒ± The Bright and Dark Sides of International Climate Action and Cooperation
sections.content: The international community faces various challenges alongside its diverse efforts to combat climate change. The ASEAN region possesses renewable energy potential amounting to 20TW [32], and China is making positive changes, such as successfully altering water flows through ambitious reforestation missions [69]. Additionally, Asian farmers are combating climate change by utilizing biological control methods like ducks, drones, and biopesticides [65], and Canada's Environment and Climate Change Department has also conducted a forest and mangrove monitoring support program [72]. However, concerns are being raised that climate cooperation could weaken before peak emissions in the transition from COP30 to COP31 [61], and there are criticisms that green industrial policies alone are insufficient for net-zero decarbonization [67]. Meanwhile, news that the National Center for Atmospheric Research is slated for dismantling by the Trump administration signifies a significant setback for climate science research [81], and criticism that some media outlets report on net-zero 'separately' from climate change [59, 70] issues a warning that this could hinder public awareness and understanding of climate action.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the severity of the climate crisis and the multifaceted response efforts underway both domestically and internationally. However, many challenges still remain, and we have once again confirmed the urgent need to strengthen international cooperation and protect the foundation of scientific research. This concludes today's climate briefing.

summary.phenomenon: Since the first wind turbine in Korea began operation in Jeju in 1975, this year marks the 50th anniversary of wind power generation in Korea. However, the nation still relies on overseas sources for over 90% of its energy.
summary.cause: Due to the oil crisis in the 1970s, countries worldwide began developing alternative energy sources, and Korea also initiated wind power generation in response.
summary.outlook: Offshore wind power is emerging as a key alternative for increasing renewable energy supply, and it remains to be seen whether this will lead to energy independence for Korea.
